questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on lips as shown in the image below, which is associated with fever. What is the characteristic feature seen in Tzanck smear? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Multinucleated giant cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear is the characteristic diagnostic feature for Herpes labialis (HSV-1) .
  • ➤ multinucleated giant cells
  • ➤ Herpes labialis (HSV-1)

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Measles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Measles is characterized by the presence of Koplik spots on the buccal mucosa followed by a widespread rash, starting from the face and neck.

questions.text: A patient is found to have a solitary thyroid nodule. What is the first step in his management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first step in the management of a solitary thyroid nodule is to assess thyroid function with a TSH test. This guides further diagnostic and management strategies based on whether the nodule is functioning or not.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female who had a lumbar puncture continues to have a headache. Which of the following is not recommended? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fluid restriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the management of post-dural puncture headache, fluid restriction is not recommended. Instead, measures such as epidural blood patches, increased caffeine intake, and stool softeners are utilized to manage symptoms and promote recovery.

questions.text: During a police investigation, bones are uncovered at the crime scene. What key characteristic feature would be crucial in differentiating between human and animal bones, aiding forensic analysis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Precipitin test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The precipitin test is the key characteristic feature used to differentiate between human and animal bones found at a crime scene. This test is species-specific and can be applied to various tissues, including blood, semen, and bones. The formation of a precipitate upon the addition of an anti-human serum to the sample extract indicates the presence of human tissue.

questions.text: What is the action of the superior oblique muscle? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intorsion, abduction, depression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: 60-year-old obese lady underwent cholecystectomy. After 3 days she develops respiratory distress. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient, an obese post-operative case following cholecystectomy, presents with respiratory distress three days after surgery. This is highly suggestive of a pulmonary embolism, particularly in the context of immobilization and the hypercoagulable state following surgery. Pulmonary embolism is a common and serious complication of deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can occur due to immobilization and endothelial injury during surgery.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Air embolism: This is less likely in this scenario as it typically occurs immediately during or after surgical procedures involving vascular access.
  • • Option B. Air embolism:
  • • Option C. Atelectasis: While atelectasis can cause respiratory distress post-operatively, it typically does not cause sudden severe symptoms three days post-op.
  • • Option C. Atelectasis:
  • • Option D. Myocardial Infarction: Although possible, the context of recent surgery and immobilization makes pulmonary embolism a more likely diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Myocardial Infarction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-operative patients, particularly those who are obese and immobilized, the development of sudden respiratory distress should raise suspicion for pulmonary embolism due to the increased risk of deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization. Prompt diagnosis and management are crucial.
  • ➤ Note - The rule of threes (in Immobilization) whenever the patient is immobilized for more than 72 hours/ >3 days in the last 3 months that is called significant immobilization and that increases the risk of DVT and pulmonary embolism.
  • ➤ Note -

questions.text: A child was born after 8 months of the father’s death. Grandparents filed a case that the baby might not be their son’s, but DNA came positive. What is such a child called? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posthumous child

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A posthumous child is one born after the death of a parent, as seen in this scenario where the child was born 8 months after the father's death.

questions.text: Which of the following plasma protein will decrease in acute inflammation? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Albumin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Negative acute-phase reactants – Albumin, Transferrin, Transthyretin
  • ➤ Positive acute-phase reactants - CRP, hepcidin, and ferritin

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with weakness in his lower limbs and rash over the eyelids. The biopsy shows inflammation of the muscle. What is the finding shown in the image below? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gottron's papules

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Gottron's papules
  • ➤ violaceous raised lesions
  • ➤ extensor
  • ➤ joints
  • ➤ clinical marker

questions.text: Drug of choice for malaria (plasmodium vivax) in pregnancy? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chloroquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy
  • ➤ Treatment of Malaria in Pregnancy
  • ➤ Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days. To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery. For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over. Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision. Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion. Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia. Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable. Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.
  • ➤ Chloroquine – 600 mg base P.O. followed by 300 mg 12 hours later. Then 300 mg daily for next 2 days.
  • ➤ To prevent relapse during pregnancy, 300 mg is to be taken weekly until delivery.
  • ➤ For radical cure, primaquine should be postponed until pregnancy is over.
  • ➤ Parasites resistant to chloroquine should be given quinine under supervision.
  • ➤ Patients with severe anemia may need blood transfusion.
  • ➤ Folic acid 10 mg should be given daily to prevent megaloblastic anemia.
  • ➤ Complicated malaria: Artesunate IV 2.4 mg/kg at 0, 12 and 24 hours, then daily thereafter. Oral therapy (2 mg/kg) is started when the patient is stable.
  • ➤ Alternatively, Quinine IV followed by oral therapy is given.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl born out of non-consanguineous marriage presented with rachitic changes in limbs since 1½ years of age for which she has received multiple courses of vitamin D. Investigations showed the following. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate, normal calcium and parathyroid hormone levels, and increased urinary phosphate due to renal phosphate wasting, commonly due to PHEX gene mutations.

questions.text: The given congenital anomaly develops due to non-fusion of: ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arch

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts a preauricular sinus, a congenital anomaly characterized by a small opening or pit near the external ear. This condition arises due to incomplete fusion during embryonic development.
  • • Embryological Development: The external ear develops from six small hillocks of tissue that form around the 1st pharyngeal cleft, derived from the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches. These hillocks eventually merge to form the pinna (external ear). Non-fusion of Pharyngeal Arches: If there is incomplete or improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches, a preauricular sinus may form. This sinus can present as a small pit or dimple in front of the ear and can sometimes become infected or form cysts.
  • • Embryological Development: The external ear develops from six small hillocks of tissue that form around the 1st pharyngeal cleft, derived from the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches. These hillocks eventually merge to form the pinna (external ear).
  • • Non-fusion of Pharyngeal Arches: If there is incomplete or improper fusion between the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches, a preauricular sinus may form. This sinus can present as a small pit or dimple in front of the ear and can sometimes become infected or form cysts.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arch : This is incorrect. The structures formed by the 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arches do not contribute to the formation of the external ear and thus are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.
  • • Option B. 2nd and 3rd pharyngeal arch
  • • Option C. 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouch : This is incorrect. The pharyngeal pouches form internal structures such as the tonsils, thymus, and parts of the ear's auditory tube but are not involved in the formation of preauricular sinuses.
  • • Option C. 1st and 2nd pharyngeal pouch
  • • Option D. 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouch: This is incorrect. These pouches are involved in forming structures like the thymus and parathyroid glands and do not play a role in the formation of the external ear or preauricular sinuses.
  • • Option D. 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouch:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Preauricular sinuses result from the incomplete fusion of the 1st and 2nd pharyngeal arches during embryonic development, leading to the formation of a small pit or tract near the external ear.

questions.text: Which bones are cut during external DCR?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Maxillary, lacrimal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During an external Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR), the maxillary and lacrimal bones are cut to establish a new tear drainage pathway from the lacrimal sac into the nasal cavity.

questions.text: A mother delivers in a rural area under the guidance of a skilled birth attendant. Incorrect regarding the care provided by the skilled birth attendant is: (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Start breastfeeding as soon as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Clear eyes with a sterile swab

options.label: C
options.text: Bath to newborn with warm water

questions.correct_answer: C. Bath to newborn with warm water
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bath to newborn with warm water

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Newborns should not be bathed immediately after birth to prevent hypothermia; instead, they should be wiped clean and kept warm by wrapping them appropriately.

questions.text: Preferable time for IUCD insertion in a 28-year-old woman who has just delivered a healthy newborn. It was a normal vaginal delivery. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Up to 48 hours

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most preferable time for IUCD insertion after a normal vaginal delivery is within the first 48 hours postpartum to take advantage of the naturally dilated cervix and minimize expulsion risk

questions.text: A patient presents with cough, cold, fever, and malaise associated with weight loss and ascites. The patient does not have any evidence of cirrhosis and her coagulation profile is normal. Ascitic fluid analysis showed elevated adenosine deaminase. What can be done next? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start ATT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In high-prevalence countries for tuberculosis, elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) in ascitic fluid, along with clinical signs, is sufficient to start anti-tubercular therapy (ATT) without the need for invasive procedures.

questions.text: A patient presented with violent, flinging movements. Where is the lesion causing the hemiballismus seen? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subthalamic nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging movements, is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency causes xerophthalmia and follicular hyperkeratosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:
  • • Vitamin A deficiency is well known to cause a range of clinical manifestations, primarily affecting the eyes and skin. Key signs and symptoms include:
  • • Xerophthalmia : This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.
  • • Xerophthalmia : This condition includes dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, which can progress to keratomalacia and lead to blindness if untreated.
  • • Xerophthalmia
  • • Follicular hyperkeratosis : This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.
  • • Follicular hyperkeratosis : This is characterized by excessive keratin deposits in hair follicles, leading to rough, bumpy skin.
  • • Follicular hyperkeratosis
  • • Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:
  • • Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining healthy vision, immune function, and skin integrity. Its deficiency can result in:
  • • Night blindness Immunosuppression : Leading to increased susceptibility to infections. Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium , increasing the risk of infections in these areas.
  • • Night blindness
  • • Night blindness
  • • Immunosuppression : Leading to increased susceptibility to infections.
  • • Immunosuppression
  • • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • • Skin ulceration and corneal ulceration
  • • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium , increasing the risk of infections in these areas.
  • • Atrophy of urinary and respiratory tract epithelium
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Niacin : Deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia.
  • • Option B. Niacin
  • • Option C. Biotin : Deficiency can cause dermatitis, alopecia, and neurological symptoms.
  • • Option C. Biotin
  • • Option D. Vitamin B6 : Deficiency can cause anemia, dermatitis, and neurological symptoms.
  • • Option D. Vitamin B6

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the iliopubic tract?(NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: It is a thickening of the lumbar fascia

options.label: B
options.text: It lies anterior to the Poupart's ligament

options.label: C
options.text: It inserts into the pubic tubercle in front of the conjoint tendon

options.label: D
options.text: Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

questions.correct_answer: D. Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Its fibers fan out with fascia illaca laterally

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ As the iliopubic tract moves laterally from the pubic tubercle, its fibers fan out and blend with the fascia of the iliacus muscle (often referred to as the iliac fascia or fascia iliaca). This provides a connection between the structures of the anterior abdominal wall and the pelvic sidewall.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of peripheral artery disease presents with symptoms of intermittent claudication and ischemic rest pain in the lower extremities. Further evaluation reveals a significant stenosis in the femoropopliteal artery. The patient is scheduled for a femoropopliteal bypass procedure, and the surgeon must choose the appropriate graft material for the procedure. Which is the best graft for a femoropopliteal bypass?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Great saphenous vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The great saphenous vein is the preferred graft material for femoropopliteal bypass due to its superior patency rates and longevity compared to synthetic grafts like Dacron or polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE).

questions.text: What is the type of pelvis shown below? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Gynecoid Pelvis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Given image shows a Gynecoid pelvis.
  • • Based on the shape of the inlet female pelvis can be divided into 4 types: Gynecoid (50%) Android (25%) Anthropoid (20%) and platypelloid (5%) (Caldwell-Molloy anatomical classification)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Gynecoid pelvis, which is slightly oval or round in the transverse axis, is the most common and ideal type for childbirth.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition page 403, William’s textbook of Obstetrics page 34
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition page 403, William’s textbook of Obstetrics page 34

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety? ( INICET May 2021
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) LH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Beta hCG is structurally and functionally similar to Luteinizing Hormone (LH). Its primary role is to support the corpus luteum during early pregnancy, preventing its involution.

questions.text: Major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fetal urine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Fetal urine production begins from 8-11 weeks period of gestation In the first trimester, amniotic fluid is generally composed of extracellular fluid secreted across the amnion via trans membranous flow; across the fetal vessels on placental surface via intramembranous flow; and via transcutaneous flow across fetal skin. Fetal urine is the major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks.
  • • Fetal urine production begins from 8-11 weeks period of gestation
  • • In the first trimester, amniotic fluid is generally composed of extracellular fluid secreted across the amnion via trans membranous flow; across the fetal vessels on placental surface via intramembranous flow; and via transcutaneous flow across fetal skin.
  • • Fetal urine is the major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Fetal skin: While fetal skin does contribute to amniotic fluid in the first trimester through transcutaneous flow, it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.
  • • Option B. Fetal skin:
  • • Option C. Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid contributes to the amniotic fluid but not as significantly as fetal urine post 20 weeks.
  • • Option C. Fetal lung fluid:
  • • Option D. Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma contributes indirectly to amniotic fluid via transmembranous flow, but it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.
  • • Option D. Maternal plasma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fetal urine is the major contributor to amniotic fluid volume post 20 weeks of gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 34, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: The instrument shown below is used for estimating for hemoglobin levels. What does it measure? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acid hematin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sahli’s Hemoglobinometer estimates hemoglobin levels by converting hemoglobin into acid hematin, which is then compared to a color standard.

questions.text: Shield ulcer is seen in:( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Spring catarrh

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Spring catarrh, also known as vernal keratoconjunctivitis, is a chronic allergic condition of the conjunctiva that typically occurs in children and young adults during the spring and summer months. It is characterized by symptoms such as itching, redness, and photophobia, and may lead to the development of shield ulcers on the cornea.

questions.text: A middle aged Indian male came to Derma OPD with the lesion as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. The microscopic examination of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystinuria: Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad. It is an autosomal recessive condition.
  • ➤ Cystinuria is one of the inborn errors of metabolism included in the Garrod’s tetrad.
  • ➤ an autosomal recessive
  • ➤ The disorder is attributed to the deficiency in transport of amino acids Signs and symptoms include:
  • ➤ Signs and symptoms include:
  • ➤ Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria . Crystalluria and calculi formation . In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test . Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography. Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake . Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.
  • ➤ Abnormal excretion of cystine and to a lesser extent lysine, ornithine and arginine. Hence the condition is also called Cystine-lysinuria .
  • ➤ Cystine-lysinuria
  • ➤ Crystalluria and calculi formation . In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  • ➤ . In acidic pH, cystine crystals are formed in urine
  • ➤ Obstructive uropathy, which may lead to renal insufficiency
  • ➤ Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test . Urine is made alkaline with ammonium hydroxide and sodium cyanide is added. Cystine, if present, is reduced to cysteine. Then add sodium nitroprusside to get a magenta-red colored complex. Specific aminoaciduria may be confirmed by chromatography.
  • ➤ Cyanide-Nitroprusside Test is a screening test
  • ➤ Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake . Solubility of cystine is increased by alkalinization of urine by giving sodium bicarbonate.
  • ➤ Treatment is to increase urinary volume by increasing fluid intake

questions.text: Zellweger syndrome is caused by the defect of which of the following organelles?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In Zellweger syndrome, there are empty peroxisomes in all body cells causing defect in alpha-oxidation and oxidation of VLCFA. So, both phytanic acid and VLCFA accumulate. It is the most severe Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorder (PBD).

questions.text: Identify the range of the firearm wound: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Close Shot Entry Wound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Entry Wound features:
  • ➤ Entry Wound features:
  • ➤ Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible. Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent) Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound Distant range: None of these present around the wound.
  • ➤ Contact Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present just on the margin; not around the wound. Very minimally visible.
  • ➤ Contact Shot:
  • ➤ Close Shot: Burning, blackening and tattooing present in large amount around the wound (esp. blackening is prominent)
  • ➤ Close Shot:
  • ➤ Intermediate Range: Only Tattooing present around the wound
  • ➤ Intermediate Range:
  • ➤ Distant range: None of these present around the wound.
  • ➤ Distant range:

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms is seen in the baroreceptor reflex? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Negative feedback

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Baroreceptors provide negative feedback in response to an increase in blood pressure.
  • • Baroreceptors are stretch receptors located in the heart and the adventitia of the blood vessels
  • • Fig : Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism
  • • Fig
  • • Fig : Regulation of blood pressure by baroreceptor mechanism
  • • Fig
  • • Increase in blood pressure → stimulates baroreceptors → Herring’s nerves → glossopharyngeal nerves → nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla → release glutamate and activate the caudal ventrolateral medulla (CVLM) → inhibitions of rostral ventrolateral medulla (RVLM) which is the vasoconstrictor center for the brain and the heart. Simultaneously, this pathway also excites the vagal parasympathetic.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Feedforward : Incorrect. Feedforward control involves responses that anticipate changes, typically without a direct sensor feedback component, which is not applicable to the baroreceptor reflex.
  • • Option A. Feedforward
  • • Option B. Positive feedback : Incorrect. Positive feedback amplifies an initial stimulus, leading to an even greater response. In contrast, the baroreceptor reflex mitigates changes in blood pressure to restore equilibrium.
  • • Option B. Positive feedback
  • • Option D. Adaptive control regulation : Incorrect. While adaptive control involves adjustment based on feedback, it is more complex and typically involves adjustments over time to control parameters. The baroreceptor reflex specifically uses a simpler, direct negative feedback mechanism to quickly counteract changes in blood pressure.
  • • Option D. Adaptive control regulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The baroreceptor reflex is a prime example of a negative feedback mechanism in human physiology, crucial for maintaining stable blood pressure by counteracting deviations from an individual's normal blood pressure set point

questions.text: Where would you place the pulse oximeter to measure pre-ductal oxygen saturation in an infant who was born 3 minutes ago? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fetal right upper limb

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To measure preductal oxygen saturation in a newborn, place the pulse oximeter on the right upper limb. This helps in detecting any right-to-left shunt, such as in patent ductus arteriosus (PDA).

questions.text: A patient presents with a cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth, which appears bluish-red and transilluminates positively. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ranula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A ranula presents as a bluish-red, cystic swelling on the floor of the mouth that transilluminates positively, due to the accumulation of mucous from an obstructed salivary gland.
